Codeforces Round 1066 (Div. 1 + Div. 2) Editorial
By TheScrasse, 3 weeks ago,

2157A - Dungeon Equilibrium

Author: TheScrasse
Preparation: TheScrasse

Hint 1

Each value xx is independent of the others; only its own frequency matters.

Hint 2

In a balanced array, value xx must appear either 00 times or exactly xx times.

Solution
  • Each value xx is independent of the others; only its own frequency matters. In particular, for each value, find its frequency f[x]f[x].
  • In a balanced array, value xx must appear either 00 times or exactly xx times. Specifically, if it appears <x<x times at the beginning, you have to delete all its occurrences, otherwise you should keep xx occurrences. Specifically, for each xx, add f[x]f[x] to the answer if f[x]<xf[x]<x, else add f[x]−xf[x]−x.

Complexity: O(n)O(n) time. Slower solutions (e.g., O(n2)O(n2)) are allowed.

2157B - Expansion Plan 2

Author: TheScrasse
Preparation: TheScrasse

Hint 1

The order of operations does not matter. Only the number of 4s4s and 8s8s in the substring matters.

Hint 2

The black cells are the positions we can reach starting from (0,0)(0,0), if we can move orthogonally (using a 44) and diagonally (using an 88).

Hint 3

A move with an 88 is equivalent to two moves with a 44, in different directions.

Solution
  • The order of operations does not matter. So count the number of 4s4s and 8s8s, and assume there are aa 44s and bb 8s8s.
  • The grid is symmetrical. We can assume x,y≥0x,y≥0 (by making x:=|x|x:=|x|, y:=|y|y:=|y|).
  • The black cells are the positions we can reach starting from (0,0)(0,0), if we can move orthogonally (using a 44) and diagonally (using an 88).
  • In particular, since x,y≥0x,y≥0, a 44 is a step either up or right while an 88 consists of two steps, one up and one right.
  • So you make a+2ba+2b steps in total, and only a+ba+b of them can be in the same direction.
  • The necessary and sufficient conditions are
    • a+2b≥x+ya+2b≥x+y (you need to be able to perform x+yx+y steps, either up or right, to reach (x,y)(x,y));
    • a+b≥max(x,y)a+b≥max(x,y) (you need to be able to perform yy steps up and xx steps right).

2157C - Meximum Array 2

Author: TheScrasse
Preparation: TheScrasse

Hint 1

For each element, determine whether it belongs to a MEXMEX constraint, a minmin constraint, both, or none.

Hint 2

If an element belongs to both a MEXMEX constraint and a minmin constraint, it is useless for both constraints.

Hint 3

If an element only belongs to a minmin constraint, you can set it to kk for convenience.

Hint 4

What's the "fastest" way to satisfy a MEXMEX constraint? What about several constraints simultaneously?

Solution

For each element, determine whether it belongs to a MEXMEX constraint, a minmin constraint, both, or none.

  • If an element is covered by a minmin constraint, it must be ≥k≥k, and ideally it should be =k=k (so that the constraint is immediately satisfied).
  • If an element is covered by a MEXMEX constraint, it must be ≠k≠k, and ideally it should be <k<k (to make the constraint easier to satisfy).

Then

  • If an element is not covered by any constraints, it does not matter, and you can set it to any value.
  • If an element belongs to both a MEXMEX constraint and a minmin constraint, it is useless for both constraints, but you must set it to something both ≠k≠k and ≥k≥k. For example, you can set it to k+1k+1.
  • If an element only belongs to a minmin constraint, it is optimal to set it to kk.
  • The remaining elements are the ones which are only covered by a MEXMEX constraint. In order to be satisfied, a MEXMEX constraint must contain at least kk such elements (because it must contain all the elements between 00 and k−1k−1, which would violate a minmin constraint). In particular, assigning i mod ki mod k at the ii-th such element works (if a MEXMEX constraint contains kk such elements, their values are [0,1,…,k−1][0,1,…,k−1], possibly shifted).

Complexity: O(nq)O(nq) or O(n+q)O(n+q) per test case.

Bonus: in the above solution, we assign i mod ki mod k to the ii-th element only covered by MEXMEX constraints. However, assigning ai=i mod kai=i mod k to such elements (where ii is the position in the whole array, instead of the position only considering such elements) also works. Can you prove it?

2157D - Billion Players Game

Author: TheScrasse
Preparation: TheScrasse

Hint 1

The worst case is either x=lx=l or x=rx=r. So you can assume that xx is either ll or rr, but you don't know which one.

Hint 2

There exists an optimal strategy where a prefix of offers (after sorting) is accepted using the third option, and a suffix of elements is accepted using the second option.

Hint 3

There exists an optimal strategy where (in addition to the previous properties) at most one offer is rejected.

Solution

The worst case is either x=lx=l or x=rx=r.
Sketch of proof. After fixing the strategy, the number of coins as a function of xx is a straight line.
Then, in order to test a strategy, it is enough to evaluate it at x=lx=l and x=rx=r and pick the minimum.

There exists an optimal strategy where a prefix of elements (after sorting) is red, and a suffix of elements is blue.
Sketch of proof. Use exchange argument. For example, if y≤zy≤z, yy is white and zz is red, then we get x−zx−z coins. If we make yy red and zz white, we make x−yx−y coins instead.

There exists an optimal strategy where (in addition to the previous properties) at most one element is white.
Sketch of proof. If x≤yx≤y, and they are both white, we can make xx red and yy blue instead.

  • Try all possibilities for the white element. So there are O(n)O(n) candidate strategies.
  • We can test a strategy in O(1)O(1): find the number of coins as a function of xx using prefix sums, and evaluate it in ll and rr to check the actual worst case.

Complexity: O(nlogn)O(nlog⁡n)

2157E - Adjusting Drones

Author: TheScrasse
Preparation: TheScrasse

Hint 1

The order of the elements does not matter.

Hint 2

Solve the problem with k=1k=1.

Hint 3

Iterate over elements from right to left and find their final value if k=1k=1.

Hint 4

Find the value of each element over time. Can you calculate the value of some element after a fixed number mm of operations?

Hint 5

Binary search the answer.

Solution

The order of the elements does not matter. So let's sort the elements in increasing order. Also, we have the freedom to choose the tiebreaker rule (i.e., which elements are increased by 11).

  • Assume the process stops when all the elements are distinct (i.e., k=1k=1). Let's find the configuration b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn at that point. If some elements are equal, the rightmost does not increase.
  • From right to left, if the initial value is aiai, then bibi is the smallest x≥aix≥ai not present in bb yet.
  • If we look at a single element over time, it has values ai,ai+1,…,bi,bi,…,biai,ai+1,…,bi,bi,…,bi.

  • The maximum number of occurences of one element does not increase after one operation (if value xx appeared ≤k≤k times, it produces ≤k−1≤k−1 copies of x+1x+1, and at most one other copy of x+1x+1 survives).
  • So we can binary search the answer. Using the process described earlier, we can retrieve the configuration after mm moves in O(n)O(n).

Complexity: O(nlogn)O(nlog⁡n) time (there also exist "magical" O(n)O(n) solutions!)

Code

350380783

2157F - Git Gud

Author: TheScrasse
Preparation: TheScrasse

Hint 1

How would you write the checker for this problem? (How to check efficiently whether a submission gets AC or WA)?

Hint 2

After you choose yy, calculating the optimal ll is easy. From now, let's denote the operations only using yy.

Hint 3

Consider some naive strategies: for example, [1,2,…,n−1][1,2,…,n−1], or [n−1,n−2,…,1][n−1,n−2,…,1]. Why are they bad? How to improve them?

Hint 4

You can fix your skill modulo 22, then modulo 44, then modulo 88, etc., but that's still a bit too inefficient.

Hint 5

Try with a different modulo.

Solution

As a warm-up, think about how we would write the checker for this problem.

We can store the set of all the possible skills (initially, all integers in [1,n][1,n]), and perform operations in O(1)O(1) (we have to remove yy and insert y+ly+l).

As a consequence, the optimal value of ll is the smallest one such that y+ly+l is already in the set. Since we know how to determine the optimal ll for a fixed yy, let's denote the operations only using yy.

  • Naive strategy 1: use operations 1,2,…,n−11,2,…,n−1. Unfortunately, they are too "increasing".
  • Naive strategy 2: use operations n−1,n−2,…,1n−1,n−2,…,1. Unfortunately, they are too long.

Better strategy:

  • Fix our skill modulo 22 using operations n−1,n−3,n−5,…n−1,n−3,n−5,…
  • Fix our skill modulo 44 using operations n−2,n−6,n−10,…n−2,n−6,n−10,…
  • ……

The cost is O(nlogn)O(nlog⁡n) (≈log2n≈log2⁡n layers, O(n)O(n) per layer). We use very few "increasing" operations (11 per layer): we can try to use more (and maybe use less layers).

Generalization:

  • Fix our skill modulo 33 using operations n−2,n−5,n−8,…,n−1,n−4,n−7,…n−2,n−5,n−8,…,n−1,n−4,n−7,…
  • Fix our skill modulo 99 using operations n−6,n−18,n−30,…,n−3,n−12,n−21,…n−6,n−18,n−30,…,n−3,n−12,n−21,…
  • ……

Now we have ≈log3n≈log3⁡n layers and 22 "increasing" operations per layer.

If we use modulo mm, we have ≈logmn≈logm⁡n layers, each with cost ≈n≈n, and m−1m−1 "increasing" operations per layer, each with cost 10001000.

We should choose m≈n−−√3m≈n3. So the total cost is around

(logmn)(n+1000m)=3(n+1000n−−√3)<4n(logm⁡n)(n+1000m)=3(n+1000n3)<4n

if $n = 250\,000$.

2157G - Isaac's Queries

Author: KLPP
Preparation: KLPP

Hint 1

Apply prefix XOR. So, instead of information about al⊕al+1⊕…⊕aral⊕al+1⊕…⊕ar, assume you can ask information about al⊕aral⊕ar.

Hint 2

Find whether the highest bit of every aiai (viewed as 3030-bit integer) is 00 or 11. You can assume that a1a1 has highest bit 00.

Hint 3

You get two blocks. Recurse.

Hint 4

Solve every block in the most efficient way possible.

Solution

Apply prefix XOR. So, instead of information about al⊕al+1⊕…⊕aral⊕al+1⊕…⊕ar, we assume we can ask information about al⊕aral⊕ar.

Let's build a trie containing the aiai. Specifically, each node corresponds to a prefix of the binary representation, and contains positions ii such that aiai has that prefix. It is not possible to recover the aiai uniquely, but we can set bits to 00 without loss of generality if they do not impact any queries. Then, in order to calculate the answer for some (l,r)(l,r), we have to find the LCA of the corresponding nodes.

Suppose we are in some node of the trie containing kk values. We want to recurse into two children, depending on the next bit. This is possible by asking the query.

Specifically, suppose that a node contains positions p1,p2,…,pkp1,p2,…,pk. In order to recurse, we need to ask queries between some pairs. We choose this pairs greedily, by calculating a minimum spanning tree (the edges have cost 1pj−pi+11pj−pi+1). It can be also shown that, in the minimum spanning tree, the picked edges contain either p1p1 or pkpk, which makes the implementation easier.

Empirically, this solution requires around 88 robocoins per test case with n=100n=100.

Bonus: prove the asymptotic behavior of the solution (idea: for each (i,j)(i,j), estimate the probability that the query is performed).

Code

350380944

2157H - Keygen 3

Author: TheScrasse
Preparation: TheScrasse, Dominater069

Hint 1

Start with some "easy" pairs (n,m)(n,m). Which ones can you solve?

Hint 2

If you have a solution to (n,m)(n,m), can you transform it into a solution to (n+1,m+1)(n+1,m+1)?

Hint 3

If you have a solution to (n,m)(n,m), can you transform it into a solution to (n+1,m)(n+1,m)?

Hint 4

Find small (n,m)(n,m) with at least 20002000 solutions, and propagate these solutions to some bigger pairs.

Hint 5

Now some pairs are missing. They either have small nn, or small n−mn−m.

Hint 6

If n−mn−m is small, what can you say about the amount of pi=ipi=i?

Hint 7

If n−mn−m is small, then pnpn must be large.

Solution

For convenience, let's find "anti-bitonic" permutations instead (decreasing, then increasing). There is a bijection between bitonic and anti-bitonic permutations.

vector<int> f(vector<int> p) {
    int n = p.size();
    reverse(p.begin(), p.end());
    for (auto &u : p) u = n - u + 1;
    return p;
}

We can transform a solution to (n,m)(n,m) into a solution to (n+1,m+1)(n+1,m+1): just append n+1n+1 at the end.

We can also transform a solution to (n,m)(n,m) into a solution to (n+1,m)(n+1,m): append n+1n+1 at the end, and swap p1p1 with p1+1p1+1.

Let's divide into three cases:

  1. n≤18n≤18;
  2. n≥19n≥19, n−m≥10n−m≥10;
  3. n≥19n≥19, n−m≤9n−m≤9.

They can be solved as follows.

  1. We can find all the anti-bitonic permutations and test them in O(n⋅2n)O(n⋅2n).
  2. First, solve (18,i)(18,i) for 1≤i≤81≤i≤8 (for each ii, we have ≥2000≥2000 solutions). Transform these solutions into solutions to (n,m)(n,m).
  3. p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn must have at least n−9n−9 cycles, so it must have at least n−18n−18 fixed points (i.e., pi=ipi=i). The permutation structure is [p1,…,p1+1,p1+2,…,n][p1,…,p1+1,p1+2,…,n]: the highlighted square has at most 11 fixed point, so there are at most n−p1+1n−p1+1 fixed points. Therefore, p1≤19p1≤19, and we can iterate over all such permutations.

350381048

2157I - Hyper Smawk Bros

Author: TheScrasse
Full solution: dario2994
Preparation: TheScrasse, Dominater069

Hint 1

Solve the problem with even mm.

Hint 2

Solve the problem with t=1t=1.

Hint 3

For a fixed nn, how do "losing" mm look like?

Hint 4

Let (n,l)(n,l) (0≤m0≤m) be losing if you lose if it's your turn, the current integer is nn, and you cannot subtract ll.
If (n,l)(n,l) is losing, then (n+l,l′)(n+l,l′) with l′≠ll′≠l is winning. This means that the number of losing ll for a fixed nn is either 00, 11, or m+1m+1. Let's call nn "good", "neutral", and "evil", respectively.

Hint 5

How do the losing states (n,l)(n,l) look like?

Hint 6

Our goal is to solve t=1t=1 in O(n/m)O(n/m).

Hint 7

How to determine efficiently whether some nn is good or neutral?

Hint 8

In order to determine whether some nn is good or neutral, you can write a recursive function which terminates in O(1)O(1) on average.

Solution

Losing positions.

Let (n,l)(n,l) (0≤m0≤m) be losing if you lose if it's your turn, the current integer is nn, and you cannot subtract ll (if ll is 00, you can subtract everything).

Evil nn.

Let nn be evil if (n,0)(n,0) is losing (i.e., you lose even without constraints on the number you subtract).

Bound on the evil nn (I).

There are O(N/m)O(N/m) evil nn. Specifically, let v1,v2,…,vkv1,v2,…,vk be the evil n≤Nn≤N. Then, vi−vi−1≥m+1vi−vi−1≥m+1 (otherwise you would be able to move from an evil nn to another, contradiction).

Structure of losing positions and solution in O(t(N+m))O(t(N+m)).

If (n,l)(n,l) is losing, then (n+l,l′)(n+l,l′) with l′≠ll′≠l is winning. This means that the number of losing ll for a fixed nn is either 00, 11, or m+1m+1. Let's call nn "good", "neutral", and "evil", respectively.
Note that the losing states are O(N+m)O(N+m) in total.

Even mm.

For even mm, only the multiples of m+1m+1 are evil. In order to win, you can ensure that the last two moves have sum m+1m+1. Since m+1m+1 is odd, the last move will never be the same as the second last.

From now, let's only consider odd mm.

More structure.

Let f(n)f(n) be the distance from the largest evil n′≤nn′≤n.

There are three types of losing states.

  • (n,l)(n,l) with f(n)=0f(n)=0.
  • (n,f(n))(n,f(n)).
  • (n,f(n)/2)(n,f(n)/2) with f(n)=m+1f(n)=m+1.

This is a consequence of the slow solution described above. If ss is evil:

  • the losing states (s,l)(s,l) propagate to nn in [s+1,s+m][s+1,s+m];
  • only the losing state (s+m+12,m+12)(s+m+12,m+12) can propagate to (s+m+1,m+12)(s+m+1,m+12), and in that case s+m+2s+m+2 is evil.

So s+m+1s+m+1 cannot be good (it is either neutral or evil).

Bound on the evil nn (II).

Let v1,v2,…,vkv1,v2,…,vk be the evil n≤Nn≤N. Then, m+1≤vi−vi−1≤m+2m+1≤vi−vi−1≤m+2.

Our goal.

Let v1,v2,…,vkv1,v2,…,vk be the evil n≤Nn≤N. We want to find them in O(k)=O(N/m)O(k)=O(N/m). In this way, we can solve the problem for all mm in O(∑1≤m≤MN/m)=O(NlogM)O(∑1≤m≤MN/m)=O(Nlog⁡M).

Finding vi+1vi+1.

We have v1,v2,…,viv1,v2,…,vi, and we want to find vi+1vi+1 in O(1)O(1). It is enough to check whether vi+m+1vi+m+1 is evil. It's easier to check whether it is not evil, i.e., whether there exists a winning move.
Let's start from some nn which satisfies vj≤n≤vj+1vj≤n≤vj+1. A winning move must ensure that the opponent cannot move to an evil state (necessary condition). So there are three candidate winning moves.

  • Subtracting n−vj+1n−vj+1 (so that the opponent is too far from vj−1vj−1; this can only work if vj−vj−1=m+2vj−vj−1=m+2).
  • Subtracting n−vj2n−vj2 (so that the opponent would have to subtract n−vj2n−vj2 again to reach vjvj).
  • Subtracting n−vj−12n−vj−12 (so that the opponent would have to subtract n−vj−12n−vj−12 again to reach vj−1vj−1).

Finding vi+1vi+1 efficiently.

The previous observation provides a recursive function which can call itself up to 33 times.
The recursive function answers the question "can we win starting from (n,n−vj)(n,n−vj)?" (i.e., it is forbidden to make the move which would win immediately). This is equivalent to "is nn good or neutral?"
We want to make the average number of recursive calls less than 11, so that the function terminates in O(1)O(1).

  • We do not need the first call, because vj−1+m+1vj−1+m+1 is neutral (proved before).
  • The second call happens with probability ≲1/2≲1/2 (n−vjn−vj must be even, and the first case must not apply).
  • The third call happens with probability ≲3/8≲3/8 (n−vj−1n−vj−1 must be even, the first case must not apply, and the second call must not succeed).

So the function calls itself ≲7/8≲7/8 times on average. This is fast enough for all mm (it can be tested locally).

        +1

        Try to come up with a counterexample, and realize it's not possible.

        Specifically, this solution seems to break when there are, in this order:

        • elements with only a MEXMEX constraint (1);
        • elements with that constraint, and a minmin constraint (2);
        • elements with only constraint (1).

        But this means there is a minmin constraint inside a MEXMEX constraint, which has no solution anyway, so the input is invalid.

For E, this my O(n) solution, which isn't magical at all.

C++ Implementation
void solve(){
    int n,k;
    cin>>n>>k;
    v<int> a(n*3+5);
    for(int x,i=0;i<n;++i){
        cin>>x;
        a[x]++;
    }
    int current_count = 0, current_source = -1;
    int ans = 0;
    for(int i=0;i<a.size();++i){
        a[i] += current_count;
        if(current_source !=-1 && current_count != 0){
            ans = max(ans, i-current_source);
        }
        if(a[i]>k){
            if(current_source == -1){
                current_source = i;
            }
            current_count = a[i]-1;
        }else{
            current_source = -1;
            current_count = 0;
        }
    }
    cout<<ans<<"\n";
}

Here's a O(n)O(n) solution for E.

O(n) solution

Loop backwards from MAX_E (say 3N3N) to 11. Let EE be the energy. If cnt[E]cnt[E] is greater than kk, we need to propagate the values to the right. Propagate by incrementing RR repeatedly and doing the following.
- If a[R]=0a[R]=0, we can drop 11 frequency at this index. a[R]a[R] becomes 11.
- If a[R]=1a[R]=1, nothing happens. We pass through.
- If a[R]>1a[R]>1, we take a[R]−1a[R]−1. a[R]a[R] becomes 11.
Stop when we can drop at the current RR safely (cnt+1≤kcnt+1≤k). The answer will be the maximum R−ER−E across all EE where RR is the ending point. The complexity will be O(n2)O(n2).

To optimize this, use the fact that going over a[i]a[i] where a[i]=1a[i]=1 does nothing. Maintain a stack by pushing indices where a[i]≠1a[i]≠1. Instead of incrementing RR, we take the next value by popping from the stack. The complexity will be O(n)O(n) which can be proven after doing amortized analysis.

Although, the solution to F is correct and the margin of error is quite big. I don't think it is a practical approach during the contest.

Instead I used a similar solution that computed the cost of getting all answers to a certain modulo.

So we start with dp[1]=-1000, dp[x]=inf for all other x. The cost of starting position is -1000 as the first transition is discounted.

Then for increasing i,j we compute dp[i*j]=min(dp[i*j],dp[i]+n-n/j+1000*j)

The lowest cost is dp[y], y>=n.

My solution got down to cost of 923188 https://codeforces.com/contest/2157/submission/350336820 What was the lowest cost anyone got?

    I got a much better result after contest ends, though the ideas are similar.

    My idea

    We need to construct a tree of minimal cost with root nn, where the depth of the tree costs 1000⋅d1000⋅d and edge (i,j)(i,j) costs |j−i||j−i|.

    A straightforward solution is to construct a chain of length l=Θ(n−−√)l=Θ(n), and the ii-th node on the chain is a chain representing a range of length ii. This construction gives us a cost of about 2n+10002n−−√≈1.2×1062n+10002n≈1.2×106.

    To be simplified, define the tree above as T(i)T(i). Now we construct a chain of length l=Θ(n−−√3)l=Θ(n3), and the ii-th node on the chain has a son of T(i−1)T(i−1) representing a range. Through this we can achieve a cost of about 3n+10003n−−√3≈8.5×1053n+10003n3≈8.5×105.

    Code: 350368299

      +13

      In an optimal solution you should find for each value where to jump to. Then the overall cost is equal to the sum of lengths of the jumps plus 1000 times the longest path. To solve the problem we can minimize for a fixed longest path what is the minimum cost of the jumps using dynamic programming. DP(n,k)DP(n,k) is the minimum cost of the jump (without the cost of the longest path) for nn values and kk longest path. This can be computed in O(n2⋅k)O(n2⋅k) fixing the smallest number that jumps directly to the end, before that point all path will end at that number and will have length k−1k−1 at most, after that the longest path can have length kk. It turns out you can speed up this dp using knuth optimization and compute it in O(n⋅k)O(n⋅k).

      Using this approach, and setting k=73k=73 is enough to solve the problem the cost is 998850998850, setting k=113k=113 solves the problem with cost 855330855330.

+13

For E, you can just simulate the process in O(n) (this seems to be magic):

Solution

For each element of the array count tow often it appears (since the order deosnt matter) Then for each i from 1 to 3*n, let x be how often it appears in the array. If x>k, we set its count to 1 and increase the count of i+1 by x-1. Additionally we can just remember where the process started and this tells us how many operations it took for the array to become ok.

Implementation: https://codeforces.com/contest/2157/submission/350355897

    I think I did something somewhat similar as an O(N) solution in python (https://codeforces.com/contest/2157/submission/350347513)

    I keep track of consecutive operations needed (operating on 1, 2, 3 etc.) and keep comparing to maxOps and if there's a point where I don't need to operate then I reset ops to 0. In order to simulate this correctly, I have to propagate i+1 to i+2 if needed before I propagate i to i+1. Then when you hit the max freq (plus like 1 or 2) that you could have at the start, then just add that final freq — 1 to your answer so you don't have to simulate to TLE.

    I only made my freq array 2*n, but effectively same complexity

Simpler sol'n to D

void solve() {
    long long n, l, r;
    cin >> n >> l >> r;
    vector<long long> v;
    long long b = 0;

    for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {
        long long a;
        cin >> a;

        if (a < l) {
            b += (l - a);       
            v.push_back(l);  
        }
        else if (a > r) {
            b += (a - r);      
            v.push_back(r);     
        }
        else {
            v.push_back(a);     
        }
    }

    sort(v.begin(), v.end());

    int k = v.size();
    for (int i = 0; i < k / 2; ++i) {
        b += (v[k - 1 - i] - v[i]); 
    }

    cout << b << "\n";
}

The remaining elements are the ones which are only covered by a MEX constraint. In order to be satisfied, a MEX constraint must contain at least k such elements (because it must contain all the elements between 0 and k−1, which would violate a min constraint). In particular, assigning i mod k at the i-th such element works (if a MEX constraint contains k such elements, their values are [0,1,…,k−1], possibly shifted).

I don't understand why i%k works if i belongs to the MEX category.

+1

You can actually solve E by just simulating the operations in a smarter way. First, as in the editorial, you see that only the frequencies matter and you can make a priority queue that takes in a struct with 3 parameters: the index, the number of things that have the same value and how many operations it took for the numbers to get to this position ( if you have five 1's, the you can put in the priority queue the triplet {1,4,0} as the numbers are all one, there are 4 of them that need to be moved and they have been moved already 0 times).

Then, the priority_queue should keep the triplets in ascending order, sorted after the first number, the other 2 won't matter as you will see further ( so {3,2,0} is before {4,0,0} and after {2,9,1} ).

Then, you take the first triplet and before you increment the numbers, you see if there are any other pairs that share the first number from the triplet. If this is true, you can simply make one pair instead of the 2, and the resulting pair, if the other 2 are {a,b,c} , {a,d,e} would be {a,b+d,max(c,e)}, because you now have b+d numbers that need to be moved and the number of moves that it would take is just the biggest of the 2.

With this, you can still have a clean nlogn solution.

    The code for this part (I know it's not that good, but it works), not in full, but I think you can imagine the rest.

    struct nod {
    int x, c, r; // x is the index, c is the number of elements with the value x and r is the number of moves that have been already made.

    bool operator<(const nod& o) const {
        return x > o.x;
    }
};

priority_queue<nod> pq;
    for (int i = mn; i <= mx; ++i) {
        if (fr[i] <= k) {
            continue;
        }

        pq.push({i+1, fr[i]-1, 1});
        fr[i]=1;
    }

    while (!pq.empty()) {
        nod nd = pq.top();
        pq.pop();
        while(pq.size() && pq.top().x==nd.x)
        {
            nd.r=max(pq.top().r,nd.r);
            nd.c += pq.top().c;
            pq.pop();
        }

      Considering even number of elements ->

      Let's say you calculate your ans based on median = ans_med, and claim the offers accordingly. you can see that, no matter what the actual rank P is this ans_med will never change. But if you had claimed any differently, then we set the actually rank P = median to give you newAnswer < ans_med. So whatever you do ans_med is the best choice.

      Basically Fix actual rank = median, now if you dont claim based on P = median, then you are obviously getting lower answer. But if you are claiming based on P = median, then even if we change actual rank to anything, the answer remains same. You can visualize this by drawing points on number line. Code — 350640234

"magical" O(n) solution for E: 350347721

solution

(translate from chinese by DeepSeek,original chat)

First, the original sequence is not important; we can try to keep only the count of each element (using a frequency array/bucket).

Each operation is equivalent to keeping only 1 instance of a value in the bucket and moving the rest to the next higher value (this process is applied to all values simultaneously).

We discuss the cases for each non-zero value in the bucket, leading to the following two scenarios:

Case 1:

#####
(none)
(none)
(none)
(none)

If there are enough "none" (empty) slots below, it will expand into:

#
#
###
(none)
....

Case 2:

####
#####
....

Here, before the above bucket meets the condition, it collides with a non-empty position below.

In this case, each downward move reduces the count of the lower element by one, while the upper element remains unchanged, until the lower element is exhausted and the upper elements catch up.

It can be observed that this scenario will eventually cause the lower elements to be "flattened" (though this may occur at different times—for example, the first few moves may flatten the lower part a bit before the upper part catches up). However, the element that takes the most time will always be the one from the upper part.

Therefore, we use a stack to simulate the above two scenarios, maintaining the situation where "pillars" (value counts) are stacked together at the current position. We use a pointer to track the actual position of the top of the stack and simulate the process of this stack of pillars moving downward one step at a time.

a O(n)O(n) solution for E

void solve() {
	int n, k; cin >> n >> k;
	vector<int> a(n+1), b(n*2+10);
	for(int i=1;i<=n;i++) cin >> a[i];
	for(int i=1;i<=n;i++) b[a[i]] ++;
	int r = 0, l = 0, ans = 0;
	for(int i=1;i<=n*2;i++) {
		if(i <= r) {
			r += b[i];
		} else if(b[i] > k) {
			ans = max(ans, r-l);
			r = i + (b[i]-k);
			l = i;
		}
	}
	ans = max(ans, r-l);
	cout << ans << '\n';
}

I would say D have have a very simple solution, and its very natural to think that if(a[n/2]>=l && a[n/2]<=r) then we select a[n/2] as p because by median property we can say that sum of absolute difference between all elements and its median is minimum otherwise p = min(a[n/2],r) and p = max(a[n/2],l) and the code is ~~~~~ void solve() { ll n, l, r; cin >> n >> l >> r; vector a(n); repp(i, n) { cin >> a[i]; } sort(all(a)); ll ans = 0; ll median = a[n / 2]; median = max(l, a[n / 2]); median = min(r, median); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { ans += abs(a[i] — median); } cout << ans << endl;

} ~~~~~

Another solution to problem D using the mathematical median

We need to find the maximum possible score you can guarantee, that is, the minimum score we can win if we iterate all possible values of pp over [l,r][l,r].

Let's solve an easier version of a problem with l=1l=1 and r=1e9r=1e9.

The mathematical median has an exciting property, the minimised absolute deviation property. In other words, for a sorted array a1,a2,...,ana1,a2,...,an, ∑ni=1|m−ai|∑i=1n|m−ai| will be minimized if m=a⌊n2⌋m=a⌊n2⌋, the array's median.

The answer would be ∑ni=1|m−ai|∑i=1n|m−ai|.

Now, let's return to the original problem.

Define mm as the position in [l,r][l,r] where we will win the minimum score. After we sort the array aa, we will set the value of mm to be the median of aa if it is in the range [l,r][l,r]. Otherwise, m=lm=l if the median is strictly less than ll, and m=rm=r if the median is strictly greater than rr.

The answer would be ∑ni=1|m−ai|∑i=1n|m−ai|, and the overall complexity is O(nlogn)O(nlogn).

My submission: 350340949

I did a O(N) solution for E, will leave the explanation if interested. It has the same objective of the editorial explanation, looking for the final value for each i where frec[i] > k.

Observation 1: Given an i where frec[i] > k, none of the indices j > i, where frec[j] > 0, will be the final value for i. The reason is that each time a frequency is passed from an index to another, atleast k positions are passed. So if the next index has a frequency > 0, then it will be atleast k+1 and will continue passing it on.

Think of indices with frec[index] > 0, as Xavi Alonso's (football player), every time a ball is given to index, it will pass it to the next index.

Observation 2: All elements that passed values will always be > 0. This means we are only interested in the elements with frequency = 0, and once an element with frequency = 0, passes the ball (value), it will become greater than 0.

We have frequencies different than 1 and frequencies equal to 1. Let an array A be a path where A_i, passed its frequencies to A_{i+1}. Note that all elements except the last will equal to 1.

Implementation: Iterate from 3*N to 1. We will store the values with frequency different than 1, and the idea is to maintain a sorted array with elements from [i+1, 3*n] that have frequency != 1. If the ith element has frequency > k, then iterate the array and start checking if it can be an endpoint or not, and accumulate the total frequencies passed. Note that there will be 0s and elements greater than 1, one will be a possible endpoint the other will add more frequencies. 350497294


    for(int i = 3*n; i>=1; --i){
        if(frec[i] > k){
            ll cur = 0;
            while(pending.size()){
                auto [idx, val]= pending.back();
                pending.pop_back();
                
                int right = cur + frec[i]+val; // assumes all elements from [i, idx] are already 1, so it only considers the sum without taking the 1s into account. This makes the 0s, -1s
                if(right <= k){
                    ans = max(ans, idx-i);
                    pending.push_back({i, right-1});
                    break;
                }
                cur += val;
            }
        }else{
            pending.push_back({i,frec[i]-1}); // It will be assumed that all frequencies 
        }
    }

We can actually analyze and solve problem F in a provably optimal way. The main idea is to analyze the problem the full tree of operations, instead of trying to construct the passes in blocks of mm.

As in the editorial, we'll think of the state as a set of "alive values" which are possible. Each operation on must take an alive value yy and merge yy into the closest y+ly+l that's currently alive: there's no reason to pick a bigger ll, since that wouldn't help us any more than just going to y+ly+l, and there's no reason to pick a smaller ll, since we could just delay the operation until we do merge y+ly+l (the relative order will never change, so the cost will be the same).

Let's fix the number of decreasing passes of operations as dd, so that we pay 1000(d−1)1000(d−1) for the passes.

Now, let's consider the (ordered) tree of merges of alive values over each pass. This tree should have d+1d+1 layers, with nn leaves at the bottom, and each node's children form an interval of the next layer. A node's actual "alive value" is just the index of its rightmost leaf, since we always merge to the right; let the rightmost leaf of node nn be r(n)r(n).

Now, let's analyze the total cost of the merges. Consider an interior node nn with children c0,c1,…ctc0,c1,…ct. We have r(n)=r(ct)r(n)=r(ct), and we'll merge them from right to left over the pass and pay

(r(n)−r(ct−1))+(r(n)−r(ct−2))+⋯+(r(n)−r(c0))(r(n)−r(ct−1))+(r(n)−r(ct−2))+⋯+(r(n)−r(c0))

We can simplify these differences, though: if we have sz(n)sz(n) be the number of leaves in the subtree of nn, note that

r(ct)−r(ci)=sz(ci+1)+sz(ci+2)+⋯+sz(ct)r(ct)−r(ci)=sz(ci+1)+sz(ci+2)+⋯+sz(ct)

Thus, the cost instead equals

sz(ct)+(sz(ct−1)+sz(ct))+⋯+(sz(c1)+sz(c2)+⋯+sz(ct))sz(ct)+(sz(ct−1)+sz(ct))+⋯+(sz(c1)+sz(c2)+⋯+sz(ct))

Regrouping, we have the cost equals

0sz(c0)+1sz(c1)+2sz(c2)+⋯+tsz(ct)0sz(c0)+1sz(c1)+2sz(c2)+⋯+tsz(ct)

Now, we can change the order of summation to group by each leaf. Let's label each leaf $i$ with an array aiai of length dd corresponding to the path we take from the root to this leaf: leaf ii is in the ai,jai,j-th child at layer jj. Then, the total cost of all operations is exactly

1000(d−1)+∑ni=1∑dj=1ai,j1000(d−1)+∑i=1n∑j=1dai,j

Thus, we can actually construct our tree by picking the smallest possible arrays aiai. After fixing dd, we can construct at most (d+w−1w)(d+w−1w) arrays aiai with total sum ww. We can pick them greedily, and then construct the tree afterwards.

For n=250000n=250000, it turns out the optimal depth is d=113d=113 and the optimal cost is 855330855330. This is the smallest depth where all leaves have weight ≤3≤3.

Here's my method for estimating the expected cost of problem G.

On the ii-th layer of the trie. It divides the nn nodes into 2i2i parts. Consider what the MST of each part looks like.

Well, the longest edge connects the node with the minimum index and the maximum index, and then the node inside the range connects to the further node of the node with the minimum index and the maximum index.

In ii-th layer, 'cause the testcases are generated randomly, we consider each part has a close number of nodes. So we consider each part has n2in2i nodes.

The range of the kk node randomly chosen from nn nodes is r=k−1k+1nr=k−1k+1n. For the other nodes, we consider the worst situation; the rest nodes are distributed near the middle of the range. So the distances are d2,d2+1,⋯d2,d2+1,⋯.

I used the following Python script to calculate it:

total = 0
for i in range(0, 6):
    n = 100
    delta = (n - (1 << i)) / (n + (1 << i)) * n
    print(delta)
    ans = 0
    ans += 1 / delta
    for j in range(1, int((n / (1 << i)) / 2)):
        ans += (1 / (delta / 2 + j)) * 2
    print(ans)
    total += ans * (1 << i)

print(total)

And the result is 9.1408416145721059.140841614572105.

struct query {
    int l, r, t;
};

bool cmp(query &a, query &b) {
    if(a.l != b.l) return a.l < b.l;
    if(a.r != b.r) return a.r < b.r;
    return a.t < b.t;
}

void solve() {
    int n,k,q;
    cin >> n >> k >> q;
    vector<query> arr(q);
    for(int i=0; i<q; i++) {
        cin >> arr[i].t >> arr[i].l >> arr[i].r;
    }
    vi ans(n, k+1);
    sort(all(arr), cmp);
    for(int i=0; i<q; i++) { 
        if(arr[i].t == 1) {
            if(i>0 && arr[i-1].t == 2 && arr[i].l <= arr[i-1].r) {
                ans[arr[i-1].r] = k;
                continue;
            }
            ans[arr[i].l-1] = k;
            continue;
        }
        if(i == 0 || (i > 0 && arr[i].l > arr[i-1].r)) {
            for(int j= arr[i].l-1, cur = 0; cur < k; j++, cur++) {
                ans[j] = cur;
            }
        }
        else if(i > 0 && arr[i-1].t == 1) {
            for(int j = arr[i-1].r, cur = 0; cur < k; j++, cur++) {
                ans[j] = cur;
            }
        }
        else if(i > 0 && arr[i-1].t == 2) {
            int  j = arr[i-1].r, l = arr[i-1].l-1;
            while(j > 0 && ans[j-1] == k+1) j--;
            for(int cur=0; cur < k && j < arr[i].r; j++, cur++) {
                ans[j] = cur;
            }
        }
    }
    for(int v:ans) cout << v << " ";
    nl;
}

For E, this my O(n) solution.

Consider paving wave to the right. When paving way, either you create a new paved way, or you merged previous paved segments into one. So creating new and merging old paved way is in 2*n.

For element i with freq[i] (a = freq in code), you can stop if you finish pave freq[i] — k entries, and the total length of the paved way is the minimum number of operation (might merging with other paved road so that the final position of the bricks will be freq[i] — (freq[i] — k) = k.

Hopefully this can help you! Please let me know if further explanation is needed

void solve() {
    int n, k;
    cin >> n >> k;
    vector<int> a(2 * n);
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        int x;
        cin >> x;
        x--;
        a[x]++;
    }

    int ans = 0;
    vector<pair<int, int>> ones;
    for (int i = 2 * n - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
        if (a[i] == 0) continue;
        pair<int, int> cur{i, i + a[i]};
        int need = max(a[i] - k, 0), tot = 0;
        while (!ones.empty() && cur.second >= ones.back().first) {
            auto [l, r] = ones.back();
            ones.pop_back();
            if (need >= l - cur.first) {
                tot += r - cur.first;
                need -= l - cur.first;
            } else {
                tot += need;
                need = 0;
            }
            cur.second += r - l;
            cur.first = r;
        }
        ans = max(ans, tot + need);
        cur.first = i;
        ones.push_back(cur);
    }
    cout << ans << '\n';
}
